parts.textUpper: How controlling light changed the world.
The earliest evidence for fire dates back nearly 440 million years. Our ancestors first used natural wildfires to flush out prey and forage for food.
parts.instruction: Tap on the wood to pick it up

parts.textUpper: In addition to the many benefits that fire provided to early humans, it also had a major impact on the innovation of tool.
parts.instruction: Tap on the axe to pick it up

parts.textUpper: Firewood would be cut to smaller pieces for Easier fire ignition

parts.instruction: Pick up the stick to continue

parts.textUpper: People to this day use the  ability to make fire with friction
Humans’ ability to control fire is among the most important technological advances in our evolutionary history.
The use of oil lamps began thousands of years ago and continues to this day although not commonly anymore.
parts.instruction: Tap on the lamp to open it

parts.textUpper: An oil lamp is an object used to produce light continuously for a period of time using an oil-based fuel source.
parts.instruction: Drag the flask to the lamp to fill it

parts.textUpper: 2 litres  of lamp oil will last about 256 hours. If you burned 6 hours a day, 2 litres of lamp oil would last you about 42 days
parts.instruction: Drag the stick to the lamp’s wick to light the lamp

parts.textUpper: Oil lamps burned cleaner, with less smoke, than candles and other sources of light before electricity.
A light bulb is also known as an incandescent light bulb, incandescent lam or an incandescent light globe. The average lifetime of a household light bulb is around 1,000 hours.
parts.instruction: Tap on the switch to turn on the light bulb

parts.textUpper: Nowadays we have light wherever we go
